original_data.question: A 32-year-old Caucasian woman is referred to a gastroenterologist by her family physician for 8 months of abdominal pain, foul-smelling diarrhea with floating, bulky stools, weight loss, and macrocytic anemia. Her personal history is relevant for allergic rhinitis. Physical examination shows grouped, erythematous papulovesicular lesions on her arms, torso, and abdomen. Which of the following is the most appropriate approach for the management of this patient?

model_response:
The patient's symptoms are suggestive of small intestinal disease, and her skin lesions are consistent with those seen in dermatitis herpetiformis, a cutaneous manifestation of gluten-sensitive enteropathy (celiac disease). The diagnosis is confirmed by duodenal or jejunal biopsy, and by the presence of IgA antibodies to tissue transglutaminase. The treatment is a gluten-free diet.

Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant that may have a role in the management of diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome. Octreotide is a somatostatin analog that may be useful in the management of diarrhea due to carcinoid syndrome or vagotomy. Methysergide maleate is a serotonin antagonist that may be useful in the management of diarrhea due to medullary carcinoma of the thyroid.

### COMMENTS:

Celiac disease is an inflammatory disease of the small bowel occurring in genetically susceptible individuals, triggered by the ingestion of gliadin, a protein component of wheat, oat, rye, and barley. The disease is associated with the human leukocyte antigen (HLA)-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8. The ingestion of gluten leads to the loss of intestinal epithelial cells, with subsequent activation of an inflammatory response that causes villous atrophy and crypt hyperplasia.

The diagnosis of celiac disease is suspected in this patient on the basis of her clinical presentation and the presence of dermatitis herpetiformis. The diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of IgA antibodies to tissue transglutaminase. The treatment is a gluten-free diet.

Amitriptyline and methysergide maleate are used to manage diarrhea associated with carcinoid syndrome. Octreotide is used to manage diarrhea associated with vagotomy and dumping syndrome.

###Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A group distinguished by classification according to physical features. This group, also called Europoid, centers around the Mediterranean Sea but includes other parts of Europe. (from Winick: Dictionary of Anthropology, 1972; American Heritage Dictionary, 2d College ed)
Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Physicians who specialize in treating diseases of the DIGESTIVE SYSTEM.
Those physicians who have completed the education requirements specified by the American Academy of Family Physicians.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
Sensation of discomfort, distress, or agony in the abdominal region.

An increased liquidity or decreased consistency of FECES, such as running stool. Fecal consistency is related to the ratio of water-holding capacity of insoluble solids to total water, rather than the amount of water present. Diarrhea is not hyperdefecation or increased fecal weight.
A number that can have its decimal point in any position.
Anemia characterized by larger than normal erythrocytes, increased mean corpuscular volume (MCV) and increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH).
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.
This gene is involved in inflammatory processes and has been identified as a therapeutic target in persons with asthma.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
A small (less than 5-10 mm) elevation of skin that is non-suppurative.
The superior part of the upper extremity between the SHOULDER and the ELBOW.
The central part of the body to which the neck and limbs are attached.
That portion of the body that lies between the THORAX and the PELVIS.
Performing or possessing executive duties; acting as a supervisor or manager.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
